info.name: ALX Project Nexus - Movie Recommendation API
info.description: ## Project Nexus Movie API The **Project Nexus Movie API** provides trending and recommended movie data, user account management, and personalized recommendations. It integrates with **TMDB** for movie data, caches responses in **Redis** for performance, and delivers consistent **JSON responses**. Designed for frontend, mobile, and backend developers needing user-specific movie data. --- ## Disclaimer The examples in this documentation have been modified for security reasons. Sensitive values such as **JWT tokens, user IDs, and private request/response data** have been removed or altered. The sample requests and responses are **illustrative only** and may not reflect the exact live data. For interactive testing, please visit the [Swagger UI](https://alx-project-nexus-movie-api.onrender.com/api/v1/docs/schema/swagger-ui/) hosted with the API. --- ## API Capabilities **Public Endpoints** - Access trending movies, search movies, and view genres **without authentication**. **Protected Endpoints** - User-specific operations such as managing favorites, profile edits, and recommended movies require **JWT authentication**. **Rate Limits** - Authenticated users: 1000 requests/day - Anonymous users: 500 requests/day **Protocol**: HTTPS only (HTTP requests are redirected to HTTPS) **Response Format**: JSON; errors returned under the `error` key --- ## Functionality - View a list of trending movies (up to 60, ranked by popularity, paginated) - Search movies by title - Save movies to a personal watchlist or catalog - Create and manage user accounts and profiles - Access personalized movie recommendations --- ## Getting Started ### Public (Read-Only) Users - No sign-up or API key required - Simply make requests to public endpoints Example: ``` markdown GET https://alx-project-nexus-movie-api.onrender.com/api/v1/movies/ ``` ### Authenticated Users 1. Create a user account via `/users/` (POST) 2. Obtain a JWT token via `/token/` (POST) 3. Include the token in the Authorization header: ``` powershell Authorization: Bearer ``` - Access protected endpoints such as favorites, profile edits, and recommended movies --- ## Authentication - **JWT-based**: Access and refresh tokens via `/token/` and `/token/refresh/` - **Errors**: - 401 Unauthorized → Missing or invalid token - 403 Forbidden → Insufficient permissions --- ## Rate Limiting Every response includes headers to track usage: - `X-RateLimit-Limit`: Maximum requests per day - `X-RateLimit-Remaining`: Requests left in the current window - `X-RateLimit-Reset`: Time when the window resets (UTC epoch seconds) **HTTP 429** → Rate limit exceeded **HTTP 503** → Temporary server overload; retry after a few minutes --- ## Error Handling - **200 OK** – Request successful - **201 Created** – Resource created successfully - **204 No Content** – Resource deleted successfully - **400 Bad Request** – Invalid payload or parameters - **401 Unauthorized** – Missing or invalid authentication token - **403 Forbidden** – Insufficient permissions - **404 Not Found** – Resource does not exist - **500 Internal Server Error** – Unexpected server error - **502 Bad Gateway** – External API failure --- ## Folder Overview - **Movies**: Trending movies, search, and details - **Genres**: List and explore movie genres - **Users**: Profile management, password updates, recommendations, favorites - **Authentication / Tokens**: Obtain and refresh JWT tokens --- ## Response Format All responses are in **JSON**. Errors follow standard HTTP status codes and are included in the JSON payload. --- ## Tips - Start with **public endpoints** to explore movie data - Use **JWT authentication** for personalized features like favorites and recommendations --- ## Need Help? - Check our tutorials or help documentation - Visit our FAQ page or developer forum for community support

item.name: Users

request.description: Creates a new user account by providing a valid **email** and matching **passwords**. If the email is not already registered, a new account is created successfully. On success, the response includes both an **access token** (valid for 5 hours) and a **refresh token** (valid for 1 day), which can be used for authenticated requests. Ommiting any of the fields will return a 400 Bad Request.

response.name: bad_request_no_data

request.description:
Retrieves user account information. Access depends on the role of the requester:

- **Superusers or staff with elevated privileges** can view the full list of registered users on the platform.
    
- **Authenticated regular users** can only retrieve their own account details.
    
- **Anonymous (unauthenticated) requests** are denied access and will receive an error.
    

This endpoint is protected and requires a valid JWT access token.

The **User Detail** endpoint returns detailed account information for a specific user, identified by their unique `user_id`. It is a protected endpoint that requires a valid JWT token. Superusers can view details for any account, while regular authenticated users can only view their own. Anonymous requests are denied access.

header.value: GET, PUT, PATCH, DELETE, HEAD, OPTIONS
GET, PUT, PATCH, DELETE, HEAD, OPTIONS
GET, PUT, PATCH, DELETE, HEAD, OPTIONS

request.description: This endpoint allows an authenticated user to update selected fields of their own account using the PATCH method. Supported updates include changing the email, first name, and last name. Each user is restricted to modifying only their own account, while anonymous requests result in a 401 Unauthorized error.

header.value: GET, PUT, PATCH, DELETE, HEAD, OPTIONS

request.description: This endpoint lets an authenticated user update personal profile details through a PATCH request. Supported updates include uploading or replacing a profile picture, adding a short bio, and setting favorite genres for personalized movie recommendations. As with other protected endpoints, only the account owner can make changes, and anonymous requests are denied with a 401 Unauthorized error.

response.name: bad request - genre setting
successful profile update

request.description: This endpoint returns a personalized list of movie recommendations for the authenticated user. If the user has set favorite genres in their profile, the results are tailored to those preferences; otherwise, the response defaults to trending movies. Access requires a valid JWT token, and anonymous requests are denied with a 401 Unauthorized error.

request.description: This endpoint retrieves the authenticated user’s personal movie catalogue, containing all the movies they have marked as favourites. It serves as the central feature of the API, enabling users to view and manage their curated list of saved movies. Access requires a valid JWT token; anonymous users are denied with a 401 Unauthorized error. The response is returned in JSON format and may be paginated for large collections.

response.name: user with no favorites

request.description: This endpoint is reserved for password reset functionality. It accepts a user’s registered email and is intended to generate a reset token and UID, which will later be delivered via email. However, this feature is not yet fully implemented and is currently non-functional. Please do not rely on it for password recovery until email delivery and link handling are completed in a future release.

response.name: user requests for password change token

item.description: The `/users` folder contains all endpoints related to user account and profile management. It allows for full control over a user’s profile, authentication, and interactions with movies. This includes creating and updating accounts, changing passwords, viewing and managing favorite movies, and accessing personalized recommendations. These endpoints are essential for implementing a secure and user-focused application experience.

item.name: Movies

request.description: This endpoint allows authenticated users to save a specific movie to their favourites catalogue, storing it in the database and linking it to their account. Each request must target a valid movie ID, and on success, the API returns a confirmation message along with the saved movie details. Anonymous requests currently cause validation errors due to missing permission handling, but this will be resolved in an upcoming update.

response.name: user saved movie to catalogue

request.description: This endpoint returns the current list of trending movies ranked by popularity score. Results are paginated, with 60 movies available in total and 5 returned per page. To optimize performance, responses are cached so that repeated requests return quickly without re-fetching data from the external API.

request.description: This endpoint removes a movie from the authenticated user’s catalogue if it exists. A valid JWT token is required. On success, the API responds with 204 No Content. If the specified movie is not in the user’s catalogue, the API responds with 404 Not Found. Unauthorized requests return 401 Unauthorized.

response.name: movie not found in user's catalogue

request.description: This endpoint retrieves the details of a single movie by its unique ID. It is publicly accessible and does not require authentication. On success, the API responds with 200 OK and the full movie object. If the movie ID does not exist or cannot be found, the API responds with 404 Not Found.

response.name: success
response.body:
{
    "movie_id": 1038392,
    "title": "The Conjuring: Last Rites",
    "popularity": 249.8959,
    "release_date": "2025-09-03",
    "description": "Paranormal investigators Ed and Lorraine Warren take on one last terrifying case involving mysterious entities they must confront.",
    "poster_url": "https://image.tmdb.org/t/p/w500/7JzOmJ1fIU43I3gLHYsY8UzNzjG.jpg",
    "genres": [
        "Horror"
    ]
}

request.description: This endpoint allows users to search for movies by providing a keyword in the query parameter `q`. The search matches against movie titles and returns a paginated list of results in JSON format. Authentication is not required. On success, the API responds with **200 OK**; if no results match the query, an empty list is returned.

response.name: success
response.body:
{
    "count": 20,
    "next": "https://alx-project-nexus-movie-api.onrender.com/api/v1/movies/search/?page=2&q=superman",
    "previous": null,
    "results": [

request.description: This endpoint returns the list of all available movie genres that users can select from when setting preferences or filtering recommendations. It is publicly accessible and does not require authentication. The response is returned in JSON format with each genre represented by its unique ID and name. A successful request returns 200 OK.

item.description: The `/movies` folder contains endpoints for retrieving, searching, and managing movies. This includes trending movies, detailed information about a specific movie, and user interactions like adding or removing movies from a personal favorites list. These endpoints are useful for both public data access and personalized user experiences.

item.name: Token Endpoints

request.description: This endpoint generates a pair of JSON Web Tokens (JWT) — an access token and a refresh token — for an authenticated user. Clients must provide valid login credentials (email and password) in the request body. The access token is used to authenticate subsequent requests, while the refresh token can be used to obtain a new access token when the old one expires. A successful request returns 200 OK with both tokens in the response body.

response.name: wrong credentials

request.description: This endpoint allows clients to obtain a new access token by submitting a valid refresh token in the request body. It is used when the access token has expired, so the user does not need to log in again. A successful request returns 200 OK with a fresh access token. If the refresh token is invalid or expired, the response will include a 401 Unauthorized error.

item.description: The `/token` folder includes endpoints for JWT-based authentication. Users can obtain access tokens, refresh them, and in some future implementations, retrieve API keys. These endpoints ensure secure access to protected resources while enabling session management for your applications.
